publicwhip.spmotion: *S1M-259# Roseanna Cunningham: Traditional Music in Scotland—That the Parliament welcomes the recent initiative set up jointly by the Scottish Arts Council and Scottish Tourist Board with the intention of developing visitor access to traditional music; calls for the extension of this initiative beyond the pilot areas of Fife, Shetland, Ross and Cromarty, the Borders and Orkney, and recognises that this work re-affirms the key role of Scotland’s indigenous arts in any cultural strategy as well as in the economic life of Scotland.
S1M-259# Traditional Music in Scotland (lodged on 8 November 1999) Linda Fabiani*, Cathy Peattie*, Bill Aitken*
S1M-259# Traditional Music in Scotland (lodged on 8 November 1999) Alex Neil*
S1M-259# Traditional Music in Scotland (lodged on 8 November 1999) Robin Harper*, Alex Fergusson*

S1M-259# Roseanna Cunningham: Traditional Music in Scotland-That the Parliament welcomes the recent initiative set up jointly by the Scottish Arts Council and Scottish Tourist Board with the intention of developing visitor access to traditional music; calls for the extension of this initiative beyond the pilot areas of Fife, Shetland, Ross and Cromarty, the Borders and Orkney, and recognises that this work re-affirms the key role of Scotland's indigenous arts in any cultural strategy as well as in the economic life of Scotland. Supported by: Linda Fabiani, Cathy Peattie, Bill Aitken, Alex Neil, Robin Harper, Alex Fergusson, Mr Jamie McGrigor*
S1M-259# Traditional Music in Scotland (lodged on 8 November 1999) Maureen Macmillan*, Dr Elaine Murray*, Mr John McAllion*, Nora Radcliffe*
S1M-259# Traditional Music in Scotland (lodged on 8 November 1999) Andrew Wilson*
S1M-259# Traditional Music in Scotland (lodged on 8 November 1999) Mr Nick Johnston*

S1M-259# Roseanna Cunningham: Traditional Music in Scotland—That the Parliament welcomes the recent initiative set up jointly by the Scottish Arts Council and Scottish Tourist Board with the intention of developing visitor access to traditional music; calls for the extension of this initiative beyond the pilot areas of Fife, Shetland, Ross and Cromarty, the Borders and Orkney, and recognises that this work re-affirms the key role of Scotland’s indigenous arts in any cultural strategy as well as in the economic life of Scotland. Supported by: Linda Fabiani, Cathy Peattie, Bill Aitken, Alex Neil, Robin Harper, Alex Fergusson, Mr Jamie McGrigor, Maureen Macmillan, Dr Elaine Murray, Mr John McAllion, Nora Radcliffe, Andrew Wilson, Mr Nick Johnston
S1M-259# Traditional Music in Scotland (lodged on 8 November 1999) Fergus Ewing*, Tommy Sheridan*

S1M-259# Roseanna Cunningham: Traditional Music in Scotland—That the Parliament welcomes the recent initiative set up jointly by the Scottish Arts Council and Scottish Tourist Board with the intention of developing visitor access to traditional music; calls for the extension of this initiative beyond the pilot areas of Fife, Shetland, Ross and Cromarty, the Borders and Orkney, and recognises that this work re-affirms the key role of Scotland’s indigenous arts in any cultural strategy as well as in the economic life of Scotland. Supported by: Linda Fabiani, Cathy Peattie, Bill Aitken, Alex Neil, Robin Harper, Alex Fergusson, Mr Jamie McGrigor, Maureen Macmillan, Dr Elaine Murray, Mr John McAllion, Nora Radcliffe, Andrew Wilson, Mr Nick Johnston, Fergus Ewing, Tommy Sheridan
S1M-259# Traditional Music in Scotland (lodged on 8 November 1999) Mrs Margaret Smith*, Donald Gorrie*

S1M-259# Roseanna Cunningham: Traditional Music in Scotland—That the Parliament welcomes the recent initiative set up jointly by the Scottish Arts Council and Scottish Tourist Board with the intention of developing visitor access to traditional music; calls for the extension of this initiative beyond the pilot areas of Fife, Shetland, Ross and Cromarty, the Borders and Orkney, and recognises that this work re-affirms the key role of Scotland’s indigenous arts in any cultural strategy as well as in the economic life of Scotland. Supported by: Linda Fabiani, Cathy Peattie, Bill Aitken, Alex Neil, Robin Harper, Alex Fergusson, Mr Jamie McGrigor, Maureen Macmillan, Dr Elaine Murray, Mr John McAllion, Nora Radcliffe, Andrew Wilson, Mr Nick Johnston, Fergus Ewing, Tommy Sheridan, Mrs Margaret Smith, Donald Gorrie
S1M-259# Traditional Music in Scotland (lodged on 8 November 1999) Fiona McLeod*
S1M-259# Traditional Music in Scotland (lodged on 8 November 1999) Mr David Davidson*

S1M-259# Roseanna Cunningham: Traditional Music in Scotland—That the Parliament welcomes the recent initiative set up jointly by the Scottish Arts Council and Scottish Tourist Board with the intention of developing visitor access to traditional music; calls for the extension of this initiative beyond the pilot areas of Fife, Shetland, Ross and Cromarty, the Borders and Orkney, and recognises that this work re-affirms the key role of Scotland’s indigenous arts in any cultural strategy as well as in the economic life of Scotland. Supported by: Linda Fabiani, Cathy Peattie, Bill Aitken, Alex Neil, Robin Harper, Alex Fergusson, Mr Jamie McGrigor, Maureen Macmillan, Dr Elaine Murray, Mr John McAllion, Nora Radcliffe, Andrew Wilson, Nick Johnston, Fergus Ewing, Tommy Sheridan, Mrs Margaret Smith, Donald Gorrie, Fiona McLeod, Mr David Davidson

Supported by: Linda Fabiani, Cathy Peattie, Bill Aitken, Alex Neil, Robin Harper, Alex Fergusson, Mr Jamie McGrigor, Maureen Macmillan, Dr Elaine Murray, Mr John McAllion, Nora Radcliffe, Andrew Wilson, Nick Johnston, Fergus Ewing, Tommy Sheridan, Mrs Margaret Smith, Donald Gorrie, Fiona McLeod, Mr David Davidson, Richard Lochhead

S1M-259# Roseanna Cunningham: Traditional Music in Scotland—That the Parliament welcomes the recent initiative set up jointly by the Scottish Arts Council and Scottish Tourist Board with the intention of developing visitor access to traditional music; calls for the extension of this initiative beyond the pilot areas of Fife, Shetland, Ross and Cromarty, the Borders and Orkney, and recognises that this work re-affirms the key role of Scotland’s indigenous arts in any cultural strategy as well as in the economic life of Scotland.
